Part of my new year resolution for 2023 is to learn at least 3 new front-end frameworks. One of these frameworks I intend to dive deeper into is Vue.js. Every time I want to learn something I try to plan first. Itâ€™s the worst thing to do is to try to run around like a headless chicken. Learning without a plan is just a glorified waste of time. So for Vue.js, I went to their site and also googled some resources online. I planned to scan all the topics that I needed to grasp first. Enough so that I can start practicing what Iâ€™ve learned in a Vue.js project.

After reading around, most of it was from the great documentation on Vue.js website, I outlined the minimum concepts I need to start learning Vue.js. Iâ€™ve outlined it in this post. If youâ€™re like me, one that is practically new to Vue.js, or worked on Vue.js before but interested in a refresher, or are just interested in reading on the topic. Feel free to read on.

Codespudâ€™s Beginner Vue.js learning plan

If youâ€™ve gone to Vue.jsâ€™ documentation page, You will find an outline of things you should learn as a prospective Vue.js programmer. I read through Vue.jsâ€™ documentation page and it was good - especially the Essentials section.

To be honest I got lost early because of some topics like the difference between Options API and Composition API. If you donâ€™t know what that is, then you were me at the beginning too. Vue.js documentation on API Preference should explain the difference between API styles.

Anyhow, there is just so much stuff to learn. For some people, this would be enough and you are free to do so. Based on the same documentation I made an outline of the topics I wanted to learn first. Also, I restricted my practice to using the Options API.

  1. Create a Vue application
  2. Templates
  3. Directives
  4. Data and Methods
  5. Computed properties
  6. Event Handling

1. Create a Vue Application

To start off, the first thing any developer wants to learn is how to make a simple application. Like most front-end frameworks nowadays, there are two ways to start creating an application. The first option is hosting an HTML page with the library CDN loaded and one is to build an application using build setup. Choose whichever way you want to start with. Whatâ€™s important is you get started early to practice.

  1. Using a CDN
<script src="https://unpkg.com/vue@3/dist/vue.global.js"></script>
  • Vuejs.org: Using a CDN
  • Vue School: Getting started with VueJS
  • Using NodeJS setup
> npm init vue@latest
  • Vuejs.org: Using NodeJS Setup
  • MDN: Vue.js - Installation

2. Templates

Vue.js has templates to define the structure of a simple application. Templates are written in HTML(or HTML-like syntax) and can include special library-specific directives and expressions to render data. 

<span>Message: {{ msg }}</span>
<p>{{ rawHtml }}</p>
  • Vuejs.org: Template Syntax
  • Vue School: Vue.js Template Syntax and Expressions

3. Directives

While working with templates, you will soon encounter directives. You will see directives as element attributes specific to Vue.js. They are prefixed with v- syntax like the example below.

<div v-for="item in items">
  {{ item.text }}
</div>
  • VueJS.org: Directives
  • CodeAcademy: Directives ðŸ’µ
  • Vuejsdevelopers.com: Understanding Directives

4. Data and Methods

Vue.js components have a data object that holds the componentâ€™s state, and methods that can be used to manipulate the state. In my opinion, the ability to manage and manipulate data is what makes front-end frameworks interesting. Itâ€™s the difference between a simple HTML page and a dynamic site.

  • VueJS.org: Data
  • Vue School: Fundamentals - Vue methods

State management

Understanding Vue.js data and methods, you will soon arrive at the concept of state management. You can use the data object and other techniques to manage the state of the application. But there are also state management libraries you can use. Vue.jsâ€™ answer to flux pattern libraries of React.js.

  • Pinia
  • Vuex

Vue.js recommends using Pinia.

5. Computed Properties

Vue.js has the concept of computed properties. Computed properties are properties that are calculated based on other properties. The contrived example below illustrates what computed properties are used for.

export default {
  data() {
    return {
      store: {
        fruits: [
          'apple',
          'mango',
          'banana',
          //...
        ]
      }
    }
  },
  computed: {
    hasMangoToSell() {
      return this.store.fruits.indexOf('mango') !== -1 ? 'Yes' : 'No'
    }
    //...
  }
}
<dl>
  <dt>Has mango to sell?</dt>
  <dd>{{ hasMangoToSell }}</dd>
  ...
</dl>
  • VueJs.org: Computed properties
  • Vue School: Computed properties
  • MDN: Using Vue computed properties

6. Event Handling

Event handling is the essence of front-end interactivity. Vue.js allows you to handle events, such as button clicks, form submissions, and more.

  • VueJS.org: Event Handling
  • VueJS.org: Form Input Bindings
  • Vue School: User events

There are other concepts a Vue.js developer needs to learn of course. I think you will encounter those topics while running through this list. Topics like components, watchers, and hooks.

Wrapping up

After the list above I plan to explore more advanced topics and start building a project. It is important to practice by building small projects, experimenting with different features, and following tutorials. Hereâ€™s my plan so far.

  1. Learn Vue.js essential concepts
  2. Debugging a VueJS application
  3. Create a blog application using Vue.js
  4. Learn Vue-Router
  5. Build for Production
